raw_text:
De Niro film leads US box office
 
 Film star Robert De Niro has returned to the top of the North American box office with his film Hide and Seek.
 
 The thriller shot straight to the number one spot after taking $22m (£11.7m) at the box office. De Niro recently spent three weeks at the top with comedy Meet The Fockers, which was at number five this week. Oscar hopefuls The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby and Sideways all cashed in on their multiple nominations with stronger ticket sales.
 
 In Hide and Seek, De Niro plays a widower whose daughter has a creepy imaginary friend. Despite lukewarm reviews from critics, the film took more than the expected $18m (£9.5m). "The element of a real actor in a psychological thriller certainly elevated it," said Bruce Snyder, president of domestic distribution at 20th Century Fox. Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby led the Oscar hopefuls with $11.8m (£6.3m), coming in at number three during its first weekend of wide release. The Aviator, a film biography of Howard Hughes that leads the Oscar field with 11 nominations, was at number six for the weekend with $7.5m (£4m). Oscar best-picture nominee Sideways entered the top ten for the first time in its 15th week of release. It came in seventh $6.3 (£3.35m). Last week's top film, Ice Cube's road-trip comedy Are We There Yet?, slipped to second place with $17m (£9m), while Coach Carter fell two places to number four, taking $8m (£4.25m) in its third week. Rounding out the top ten were In Good Company - starring Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson - Racing Stripes and Assault on Precinct 13.
llama3.2:1b: Robert De Niro's film "Hide and Seek" took US box office number one, earning $22 million after a three-week run.
It has surpassed its initial forecast of $18 million with strong ticket sales.
Other films in the top ten include Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby", Oscar hopefuls "The Aviator" and "Sideways", and sports movies "Coach Carter".

Oscar hopefuls like The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby, and Sideways saw increased ticket sales despite lukewarm reviews.
Coach Carter fell to fourth place, while Ice Cube's Are We There Yet?

Oscar hopefuls like "Million Dollar Baby," "The Aviator," and "Sideways" also performed well with their multiple nominations.
Snyder from 20th Century Fox praised De Niro's performance in psychological thriller "Hide and Seek."

The film placed first, followed by "Million Dollar Baby," "Aviator," "Sideways," "Racing Stripes," "Assault on Precinct 13," "In Good Company" starring Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson, and "Are We There Yet?

The thriller shot straight to the number one spot after taking $22m (£11.7m) at the box office.
De Niro recently spent three weeks at the top with comedy Meet The Fockers, which was at number five this week.
Oscar hopefuls The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby and Sideways all cashed in on their multiple nominations with stronger ticket sales.
In Hide and Seek, De Niro plays a widower whose daughter has a creepy imaginary friend.
Despite lukewarm reviews from critics, the film took more than the expected $18m (£9.5m).

Oscar hopefuls Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby led with $11.8m (£6.3m), coming in at number three during its first weekend of wide release, while the biopic Howard Hughes: An American Odyssey rounded out the top ten with $7.5m (£4m).

The film stars De Niro as a widower who struggles to balance his newfound fame with the challenges of raising his daughter, portrayed by Julianne Moore.
Despite mixed reviews from critics, Hide and Seek performed strongly, taking more than $18m (£9.5m) in its opening weekend.
Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby, starring Morgan Freeman, also performed well, coming in at number three with a total of $11.8m (£6.3m).
The Aviator, an Oscar-winning film biography of Howard Hughes directed by Clint Eastwood, has been nominated for eleven Academy Awards and is one of the top contenders for Best Picture.

Other notable films in this weekend's top ten include Ice Cube's road-trip comedy Are We There Yet?, which came in seventh place with $6.3m (£3.35m), and Assault on Precinct 13, starring Jessica Biel and Jake Gyllenhaal, which took up the tenth position with $5.1m (£2.85m).
